**Gun politics** is an area of [American
politics](/wiki/Politics_of_the_United_States "Politics of the United States")
defined by two opposing groups advocating for tighter [gun
control](/wiki/Gun_control "Gun control") on the one hand and [gun
rights](/wiki/Gun_rights "Gun rights") on the other. These groups often
disagree on the interpretation of laws and court cases related to firearms as
well as about the effects of firearms regulation on crime and public
safety.[1]:7 It has been estimated that [U.S. civilians own 270 million to 310
million firearms](/wiki/Estimated_number_of_guns_per_capita_by_country
"Estimated number of guns per capita by country"), and that 35% to 42% of the
households in the country have at least one gun.[2][3]

Since the mid-1990s, debates regarding firearm availability and gun violence
in the United States have been characterized by concerns about the right to
bear arms, such as found in the [Second Amendment to the U.S.
Constitution](/wiki/Second_Amendment_to_the_U.S._Constitution "Second
Amendment to the U.S. Constitution"), and the responsibility of the [United
States government](/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States "Federal
government of the United States") to serve the needs of its citizens and to
prevent [crime and deaths](/wiki/Gun_violence_in_the_United_States "Gun
violence in the United States"). Firearms regulation supporters say that
indiscriminate or unrestricted gun rights inhibit the government from
fulfilling that responsibility, and causes a safety concern, as [assault
weapons](/wiki/Assault_weapons "Assault weapons") are legal.[4][5][6]:1–3[7]
Gun rights supporters promote firearms for [self-defense](/wiki/Self-
defense#Armed "Self-defense"), [hunting](/wiki/Hunting#Shooting "Hunting"),
[sporting activities](/wiki/Shooting_sport "Shooting sport"), and security
against tyranny.[8]:96[9] Firearms regulation advocates state that restricting
and tracking gun access would result in safer communities, while gun rights
advocates state that increased firearm ownership by law-abiding citizens
reduces crime and assert that criminals have always had easy access to
firearms.[10][11]

Gun legislation, or non-legislation, in the United States is augmented by
judicial interpretations of the Constitution. In 1791, the United States
adopted the Second Amendment, and in 1868 adopted the [Fourteenth
Amendment](/wiki/Fourteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution
"Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution"). The effect of those
two amendments on gun politics was the subject of landmark [U.S. Supreme
Court](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States "Supreme Court of the United
States") decisions in 2008 and 2010, that upheld the right of individuals to
possess guns for self-defense.

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gun_politics_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Calamity_jane.jpeg/170px-
Calamity_jane.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Calamity_jane.jpeg)

[](/wiki/File:Calamity_jane.jpeg "Enlarge")

[Calamity Jane](/wiki/Calamity_Jane "Calamity Jane"), notable pioneer
frontierswoman and scout, at age 43. Photo by [H.R. Locke](/wiki/H.R._Locke
"H.R. Locke").

The American hunting tradition comes from a time when the United States was an
agrarian, subsistence nation where hunting was a profession for some, an
auxiliary source of food for some settlers, and also a deterrence to animal
predators. A connection between shooting skills and survival among rural
American men was in many cases a necessity and a '[rite of
passage](/wiki/Rite_of_passage "Rite of passage")' for those entering
manhood.[1]:9 Today, hunting survives as a central sentimental component of a
gun culture as a way to control animal populations across the country,
regardless of modern trends away from subsistence hunting and rural living.[7]

Prior to the [American Revolution](/wiki/American_Revolution "American
Revolution") there was neither budget nor manpower nor government desire to
maintain a full-time army. Therefore, the armed citizen-soldier carried the
responsibility. Service in militia, including providing one's own ammunition
and weapons, was mandatory for all men. Yet, as early as the 1790s, the
mandatory universal militia duty evolved gradually to voluntary militia units
and a reliance on a [regular army](/wiki/Regular_army "Regular army").
Throughout the 19th century the institution of the organized civilian militia
began to decline.[1]:10 The unorganized civilian militia, however, still
remains even in current U.S. law, consisting of essentially everyone from age
17 to 45, while also including former military officers up to age 64, as
codified in [10 U.S.C.](/wiki/Title_10_of_the_United_States_Code "Title 10 of
the United States Code") [§
246](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/10/246).

Closely related to the militia tradition is the frontier tradition, with the
need for self-protection pursuant to westward expansion and the extension of
the [American frontier](/wiki/American_frontier "American frontier").[1]:10–11
Though it has not been a necessary part of daily survival for over a century,
"generations of Americans continued to embrace and glorify it as a living
inheritance—as a permanent ingredient of this nation's style and
culture".[12]:21

### Colonial era through the Civil
War[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gun_politics_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Colonial era through the Civil War")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Minute_Man_Statue_Lexington_Massachusetts_cropped.jpg/170px-
Minute_Man_Statue_Lexington_Massachusetts_cropped.jpg)](/wiki/File:Minute_Man_Statue_Lexington_Massachusetts_cropped.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Minute_Man_Statue_Lexington_Massachusetts_cropped.jpg "Enlarge")

Gun politics date to Colonial America. (_Lexington Minuteman_ , representing
[John Parker](/wiki/John_Parker_\(Captain\) "John Parker \(Captain\)"), by
[Henry Hudson Kitson](/wiki/Henry_Hudson_Kitson "Henry Hudson Kitson") stands
at the town green of [Lexington, Massachusetts](/wiki/Lexington,_Massachusetts
"Lexington, Massachusetts").)

Most American school children learn about the [tyranny](/wiki/Tyranny
"Tyranny") of [King George III](/wiki/George_III_of_the_United_Kingdom "George
III of the United Kingdom"): [taxation without
representation](/wiki/No_taxation_without_representation "No taxation without
representation").[13][14] In the years prior to the [American
Revolution](/wiki/American_Revolution "American Revolution"), the British, in
response to the colonists' unhappiness over increasingly direct control and
taxation of the colonies, imposed a gunpowder embargo on the colonies in an
attempt to lessen the ability of the colonists to resist British encroachments
into what the colonies regarded as local matters. Two direct attempts to
disarm the colonial militias fanned what had been a smoldering resentment of
British interference into the fires of war.[15]

These two incidents were the attempt to confiscate the cannon of the Concord
and Lexington militias, leading to the [Battles of Lexington and
Concord](/wiki/Battles_of_Lexington_and_Concord "Battles of Lexington and
Concord") of April 19, 1775, and the attempt, on April 20, to confiscate
militia powder stores in the armory of Williamsburg, Virginia, which led to
the [Gunpowder Incident](/wiki/Gunpowder_Incident "Gunpowder Incident") and a
face off between [Patrick Henry](/wiki/Patrick_Henry "Patrick Henry") and
hundreds of militia members on one side and the Royal Governor of Virginia,
Lord Dunmore, and British seamen on the other. The Gunpowder Incident was
eventually settled by paying the colonists for the powder.[15]

According to historian [Saul Cornell](/wiki/Saul_Cornell "Saul Cornell"),
states passed some of the first gun control laws, beginning with Kentucky's
law to "curb the practice of carrying concealed weapons in 1813." There was
opposition and, as a result, the [individual
right](/wiki/Individual_and_group_rights "Individual and group rights")
interpretation of the Second Amendment began and grew in direct response to
these early gun control laws, in keeping with this new "pervasive spirit of
individualism." As noted by Cornell, "Ironically, the first gun control
movement helped give birth to the first self-conscious gun rights ideology
built around a constitutional right of individual self-defense."[16]:140–141

The individual right interpretation of the Second Amendment first arose in
_[Bliss v. Commonwealth](/wiki/Firearm_case_law_in_the_United_States#Bliss
"Firearm case law in the United States")_ (1822),[17] which evaluated the
right to bear arms in defense of themselves and the state pursuant to Section
28 of the Second Constitution of [Kentucky](/wiki/Kentucky "Kentucky") (1799).
The right to bear arms in defense of themselves and the state was interpreted
as an individual right, for the case of a concealed sword cane. This case has
been described as about "a statute prohibiting the carrying of concealed
weapons [that] was violative of the Second Amendment".[18]

The first state court decision relevant to the "right to bear arms" issue was
_Bliss v. Commonwealth_. The Kentucky court held that "the right of citizens
to bear arms in defense of themselves and the State must be preserved
entire,..."[19]:161[20]

Also during the Jacksonian Era, the first [collective
right](/wiki/Individual_and_group_rights "Individual and group rights") (or
group right) interpretation of the Second Amendment arose. In _[State v.
Buzzard](/wiki/Firearm_case_law_in_the_United_States#Buzzard "Firearm case law
in the United States")_ (1842), the Arkansas high court adopted a militia-
based, political right, reading of the right to bear arms under state law, and
upheld the 21st section of the second article of the Arkansas Constitution
that declared, "that the free white men of this State shall have a right to
keep and bear arms for their common defense",[21] while rejecting a challenge
to a statute prohibiting the carrying of concealed weapons.

The Arkansas high court declared "That the words 'a well regulated militia
being necessary for the security of a free State', and the words 'common
defense' clearly show the true intent and meaning of these Constitutions
[i.e., Arkansas and U.S.] and prove that it is a political and not an
individual right, and, of course, that the State, in her legislative capacity,
has the right to regulate and control it: This being the case, then the
people, neither individually nor collectively, have the right to keep and bear
arms." [Joel Prentiss Bishop](/wiki/Joel_Prentiss_Bishop "Joel Prentiss
Bishop")'s influential _Commentaries on the Law of Statutory Crimes_ (1873)
took Buzzard's militia-based interpretation, a view that Bishop characterized
as the "Arkansas doctrine," as the orthodox view of the right to bear arms in
American law.[21][22]

The two early state court cases, _Bliss_ and _Buzzard_ , set the fundamental
dichotomy in interpreting the Second Amendment, i.e., whether it secured an
individual right versus a collective right.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

See also: [Reconstruction era](/wiki/Reconstruction_era "Reconstruction era")

### Post Civil
War[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gun_politics_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Post Civil War")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/JABingham.jpg/170px-
JABingham.jpg)](/wiki/File:JABingham.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:JABingham.jpg "Enlarge")

Representative John A. Bingham of Ohio, principal framer of the [Fourteenth
Amendment](/wiki/Fourteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution
"Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Opperguncontrol.jpg/220px-
Opperguncontrol.jpg)](/wiki/File:Opperguncontrol.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Opperguncontrol.jpg "Enlarge")

Political cartoon by [Frederick Burr Opper](/wiki/Frederick_Burr_Opper
"Frederick Burr Opper") published in _[Puck](/wiki/Puck_\(magazine\) "Puck
\(magazine\)")_ magazine shortly after the [assassination of James A.
Garfield](/wiki/Assassination_of_James_A._Garfield "Assassination of James A.
Garfield")

With the [Civil War](/wiki/American_Civil_War "American Civil War") ending,
the question of the rights of freed slaves to carry arms and to belong to
militia came to the attention of the federal courts. In response to the
problems freed slaves faced in the Southern states, the Fourteenth Amendment
was drafted.

When the [Fourteenth
Amendment](/wiki/Fourteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution
"Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution") was drafted,
Representative [John A. Bingham](/wiki/John_Bingham "John Bingham") of
[Ohio](/wiki/Ohio "Ohio") used the Court's own phrase "privileges and
immunities of citizens" to include the first Eight Amendments of the Bill of
Rights under its protection and guard these rights against state
legislation.[23]

The debate in the Congress on the Fourteenth Amendment after the Civil War
also concentrated on what the Southern States were doing to harm the newly
freed slaves. One particular concern was the disarming of former slaves.

The Second Amendment attracted serious judicial attention with the
[Reconstruction](/wiki/Reconstruction_era_of_the_United_States "Reconstruction
era of the United States") era case of _[United States v.
Cruikshank](/wiki/United_States_v._Cruikshank "United States v. Cruikshank")_
which ruled that the [Privileges or Immunities
Clause](/wiki/Privileges_or_Immunities_Clause "Privileges or Immunities
Clause") of the Fourteenth Amendment did not cause the Bill of Rights,
including the Second Amendment, to limit the powers of the State governments,
stating that the Second Amendment "has no other effect than to restrict the
powers of the national government."

Akhil Reed Amar notes in the _[Yale Law Journal](/wiki/Yale_Law_Journal "Yale
Law Journal")_ , the basis of Common Law for the first ten amendments of the
U.S. Constitution, which would include the Second Amendment, "following [John
Randolph Tucker](/wiki/John_Randolph_Tucker_\(1823%E2%80%931897\) "John
Randolph Tucker \(1823–1897\)")'s famous oral argument in the 1887 Chicago
anarchist [Haymarket Riot](/wiki/Haymarket_Riot "Haymarket Riot") case,
_[Spies](/wiki/August_Spies "August Spies") v. Illinois_":

> Though originally the first ten Amendments were adopted as limitations on
> Federal power, yet in so far as they secure and recognize fundamental
> rights—common law rights—of the man, they make them privileges and
> immunities of the man as citizen of the United States...[24]:1270

### 20th
century[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gun_politics_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: 20th century")]

#### First half of 20th
century[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gun_politics_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: First half of 20th century")]

Since the late 19th century, with three key cases from the [pre-incorporation
era](/wiki/Incorporation_\(Bill_of_Rights\) "Incorporation \(Bill of
Rights\)"), the U.S. Supreme Court consistently ruled that the Second
Amendment (and the Bill of Rights) restricted only Congress, and not the
States, in the regulation of guns.[25] Scholars predicted that the Court's
incorporation of other rights suggested that they may incorporate the Second,
should a suitable case come before them.[26]

##### National Firearms
Act[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gun_politics_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: National Firearms Act")]

Main article: [National Firearms Act](/wiki/National_Firearms_Act "National
Firearms Act")

The first major federal firearms law passed in the 20th century was the
National Firearms Act (NFA) of 1934. It was passed after
[Prohibition](/wiki/Prohibition_in_the_United_States "Prohibition in the
United States")-era gangsterism peaked with the [Saint Valentine's Day
massacre](/wiki/Saint_Valentine%27s_Day_massacre "Saint Valentine's Day
massacre") of 1929. The era was famous for criminal use of firearms such as
the [Thompson submachine gun](/wiki/Thompson_submachine_gun "Thompson
submachine gun") (Tommy gun) and [sawed-off shotgun](/wiki/Sawed-off_shotgun
"Sawed-off shotgun"). Under the NFA, machine guns, short-barreled rifles and
shotguns, and other weapons fall under the regulation and jurisdiction of the
[Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and
Firearms](/wiki/Bureau_of_Alcohol,_Tobacco,_Firearms_and_Explosives "Bureau of
Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives") (ATF) as described by [Title
II](/wiki/Title_II_weapons "Title II weapons").[27]

##### _United States v.
Miller_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gun_politics_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: United States v. Miller")]

Main article: [United States v. Miller](/wiki/United_States_v._Miller "United
States v. Miller")

In _United States v. Miller_[28] (1939) the Court did not address
incorporation, but whether a sawed-off shotgun "has some reasonable
relationship to the preservation or efficiency of a well regulated
militia."[26] In overturning the indictment against Miller, the U.S. District
Court for the Western District of Arkansas stated that the National Firearms
Act of 1934, "offend[ed] the inhibition of the Second Amendment to the
Constitution." The federal government then appealed directly to the Supreme
Court. On appeal the federal government did not object to Miller's release
since he had died by then, seeking only to have the trial judge's ruling on
the unconstitutionality of the federal law overturned. Under these
circumstances, neither Miller nor his attorney appeared before the Court to
argue the case. The Court only heard argument from the federal prosecutor. In
its ruling, the Court overturned the trial court and upheld the NFA.[29]

#### Second half of 20th
century[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gun_politics_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Second half of 20th century")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/President_Johnson_signs_Gun_Control_Act_of_1968.jpg/220px-
President_Johnson_signs_Gun_Control_Act_of_1968.jpg)](/wiki/File:President_Johnson_signs_Gun_Control_Act_of_1968.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:President_Johnson_signs_Gun_Control_Act_of_1968.jpg "Enlarge")

President [Lyndon B. Johnson](/wiki/Lyndon_B._Johnson "Lyndon B. Johnson")
signs the Gun Control Act of 1968 into law.

The [Gun Control Act of 1968](/wiki/Gun_Control_Act_of_1968 "Gun Control Act
of 1968") (GCA) was passed after the assassinations of President [John F.
Kennedy](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy "John F. Kennedy"), Senator [Robert
Kennedy](/wiki/Robert_F._Kennedy "Robert F. Kennedy"), and African-American
activists [Malcolm X](/wiki/Malcolm_X "Malcolm X") and [Martin Luther King,
Jr.](/wiki/Martin_Luther_King,_Jr. "Martin Luther King, Jr.") in the 1960s.[1]
The GCA focuses on regulating interstate commerce in firearms by generally
prohibiting interstate firearms transfers except among licensed manufacturers,
dealers, and importers. It also prohibits selling firearms to certain
categories of individuals defined as "prohibited persons."

The [murder of musician John Lennon](/wiki/Death_of_John_Lennon "Death of John
Lennon") in 1980 and an [assassination attempt on President Ronald
Reagan](/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan "Attempted
assassination of Ronald Reagan") in 1981 led to enactment of the [Brady
Handgun Violence Prevention Act](/wiki/Brady_Handgun_Violence_Prevention_Act
"Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act") (Brady Law) in 1993 which established
the national background check system to prevent certain restricted individuals
from owning, purchasing, or transporting firearms.[30] In an article
supporting passage of such a law, retired chief justice [Warren E.
Burger](/wiki/Warren_E._Burger "Warren E. Burger") wrote:

> Americans also have a right to defend their homes, and we need not challenge
> that. Nor does anyone seriously question that the Constitution protects the
> right of hunters to own and keep sporting guns for hunting game any more
> than anyone would challenge the right to own and keep fishing rods and other
> equipment for fishing – or to own automobiles. To 'keep and bear arms' for
> hunting today is essentially a recreational activity and not an imperative
> of survival, as it was 200 years ago. '[Saturday night
> specials](/wiki/Saturday_night_special "Saturday night special")' and
> machine guns are not recreational weapons and surely are as much in need of
> regulation as motor vehicles.[31]

In 1986, Congress passed the [Firearm Owners Protection
Act](/wiki/Firearm_Owners_Protection_Act "Firearm Owners Protection Act").[32]
It was supported by the National Rifle Association and individual gun rights
advocates because it reversed many of the provisions of the GCA and protected
gun owners' rights. It also banned ownership of unregistered fully automatic
rifles and civilian purchase or sale of any such firearm made from that date
forward.[33][34]

A [Stockton, California, schoolyard
shooting](/wiki/Cleveland_Elementary_School_shooting_\(Stockton\) "Cleveland
Elementary School shooting \(Stockton\)") in 1989 led to passage of the
[Federal Assault Weapons Ban](/wiki/Federal_Assault_Weapons_Ban "Federal
Assault Weapons Ban") of 1994 (AWB or AWB 1994), which defined and banned the
manufacture and transfer of ["semiautomatic assault
weapons](/wiki/Assault_weapon "Assault weapon")" and ["large capacity
ammunition feeding devices.](/wiki/High-capacity_magazine "High-capacity
magazine")"[35]

According to journalist [Chip Berlet](/wiki/Chip_Berlet "Chip Berlet"),
concerns about gun control laws along with outrage over two high-profile
incidents involving the ATF ([Ruby Ridge](/wiki/Ruby_Ridge "Ruby Ridge") in
1992 and the [Waco siege](/wiki/Waco_siege "Waco siege") in 1993) mobilized
the [militia movement](/wiki/Militia_organizations_in_the_United_States
"Militia organizations in the United States") of citizens who feared that the
federal government would begin to confiscate firearms.[36][37]

Though gun control is not strictly a partisan issue, there is generally more
support for gun control legislation in the [Democratic
Party](/wiki/Democratic_Party_\(United_States\) "Democratic Party \(United
States\)") than in the [Republican
Party](/wiki/Republican_Party_\(United_States\) "Republican Party \(United
States\)").[38] The [Libertarian Party](/wiki/United_States_Libertarian_Party
"United States Libertarian Party"), whose campaign platforms favor limited
government, is outspokenly against gun control.[39]

##### Advocacy
groups[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gun_politics_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Advocacy groups")]

The [National Rifle Association](/wiki/National_Rifle_Association "National
Rifle Association") (NRA) was founded to promote firearm competency in 1871.
The NRA supported the NFA and, ultimately, the GCA.[40] After the GCA, more
strident groups, such as the [Gun Owners of
America](/wiki/Gun_Owners_of_America "Gun Owners of America") (GOA), began to
advocate for gun rights.[41] According to the GOA, it was founded in 1975 when
"the radical left introduced legislation to ban all handguns in
California."[42] The GOA and other national groups like the [Second Amendment
Foundation](/wiki/Second_Amendment_Foundation "Second Amendment Foundation")
(SAF), [Jews for the Preservation of Firearms
Ownership](/wiki/Jews_for_the_Preservation_of_Firearms_Ownership "Jews for the
Preservation of Firearms Ownership") (JPFO), and the [Second Amendment
Sisters](/wiki/Second_Amendment_Sisters "Second Amendment Sisters") (SAS),
often take stronger stances than the NRA and criticize its history of support
for some firearms legislation, such as GCA. These groups believe any
compromise leads to greater restrictions.[43]:368[44]:172

According to the authors of _The Changing Politics of Gun Control_ (1998), in
the late 1970s, the NRA changed its activities to incorporate political
advocacy.[45] Despite the impact on the volatility of membership, the
politicization of the NRA has been consistent and the NRA-Political Victory
Fund ranked as "one of the biggest spenders in congressional elections" as of
1998.[45] According to the authors of _The Gun Debate_ (2014), the NRA taking
the lead on politics serves the gun industry's profitability. In particular
when gun owners respond to fears of gun confiscation with increased purchases
and by helping to isolate the industry from the misuse of its products used in
shooting incidents.[46]

The [Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun
Violence](/wiki/Brady_Campaign_to_Prevent_Gun_Violence "Brady Campaign to
Prevent Gun Violence") began in 1974 as Handgun Control Inc. (HCI). Soon
after, it formed a partnership with another fledgling group called the
National Coalition to Ban Handguns (NCBH) - later known as the [Coalition to
Stop Gun Violence](/wiki/Coalition_to_Stop_Gun_Violence "Coalition to Stop Gun
Violence") (CSGV). The partnership did not last, as NCBH generally took a
tougher stand on gun regulation than HCI.[47]:186 In the wake of the 1980
murder of [John Lennon](/wiki/John_Lennon "John Lennon"), HCI saw an increase
of interest and fund raising and contributed $75,000 to congressional
campaigns. Following the Reagan assassination attempt and the resultant injury
of [James Brady](/wiki/James_Brady "James Brady"), [Sarah
Brady](/wiki/Sarah_Brady "Sarah Brady") joined the board of HCI in 1985. HCI
was renamed in 2001 to [Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun
Violence](/wiki/Brady_Campaign_to_Prevent_Gun_Violence "Brady Campaign to
Prevent Gun Violence").[48]

##### Centers for Disease Control (CDC)
restriction[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gun_politics_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Centers for Disease Control \(CDC\) restriction")]

In 1996, Congress added language to the relevant appropriations bill which
required "none of the funds made available for injury prevention and control
at the [Centers for Disease Control and
Prevention](/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention "Centers for
Disease Control and Prevention") may be used to advocate or promote gun
control."[49] This language was added to prevent the funding of research by
the CDC that gun rights supporters considered politically motivated and
intended to bring about further gun control legislation. In particular, the
NRA and other gun rights proponents objected to work supported by the
[National Center for Injury Prevention and
Control](/wiki/National_Center_for_Injury_Prevention_and_Control "National
Center for Injury Prevention and Control"), then run by [Mark L.
Rosenberg](/wiki/Mark_L._Rosenberg "Mark L. Rosenberg"), including research
authored by [Arthur Kellermann](/wiki/Arthur_Kellermann "Arthur
Kellermann").[50][51][52]

### 21st
century[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gun_politics_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: 21st century")]

In October 2003, the [Centers for Disease Control and
Prevention](/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention "Centers for
Disease Control and Prevention") published a report on the effectiveness of
gun violence prevention strategies that concluded "Evidence was insufficient
to determine the effectiveness of any of these laws."[53]:14 A similar survey
of firearms research by the [National Academy of
Sciences](/wiki/National_Academy_of_Sciences "National Academy of Sciences")
arrived at nearly identical conclusions in 2004.[54] In September of that
year, the Assault Weapons Ban expired due to a [sunset
provision](/wiki/Sunset_provision "Sunset provision"). Efforts by gun control
advocates to renew the ban failed, as did attempts to replace it after it
became defunct.

The NRA opposed bans on handguns in Chicago, Washington D.C., and San
Francisco, while supporting the [NICS Improvement Amendments Act of
2007](/wiki/NICS_Improvement_Amendments_Act_of_2007 "NICS Improvement
Amendments Act of 2007") (also known as the School Safety And Law Enforcement
Improvement Act), which strengthened requirements for background checks for
firearm purchases.[55] The GOA took issue with a portion of the bill, which
they termed the "Veterans' Disarmament Act."[56]

Besides the GOA, other national gun rights groups continue to take a stronger
stance than the NRA. These groups include the Second Amendment Sisters, Second
Amendment Foundation, Jews for the Preservation of Firearms Ownership, and the
[Pink Pistols](/wiki/Pink_Pistols "Pink Pistols"). New groups have also
arisen, such as the [Students for Concealed
Carry](/wiki/Students_for_Concealed_Carry "Students for Concealed Carry"),
which grew largely out of safety-issues resulting from the creation of [gun-
free zones](/wiki/Gun-Free_School_Zones_Act_of_1990 "Gun-Free School Zones Act
of 1990") that were legislatively mandated amidst a response to widely
publicized [school shootings](/wiki/School_shootings "School shootings").

In 2001, in _[United States v. Emerson](/wiki/United_States_v._Emerson "United
States v. Emerson")_ , the [Fifth
Circuit](/wiki/United_States_Court_of_Appeals_for_the_Fifth_Circuit "United
States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit") became the first [federal
appeals court](/wiki/United_States_court_of_appeals "United States court of
appeals") to recognize an individual's right to own guns. In 2007, in _[Parker
v. District of Columbia](/wiki/Parker_v._District_of_Columbia "Parker v.
District of Columbia")_ , the [D.C.
Circuit](/wiki/United_States_Court_of_Appeals_for_the_District_of_Columbia_Circuit
"United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit") became
the first federal appeals court to strike down a gun control law on Second
Amendment grounds.[57]

#### Smart
guns[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gun_politics_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Smart guns")]

[Smart guns](/wiki/Smart_gun "Smart gun") only fire when in the hands of the
owner, a feature gun safety advocates say eliminates accidental firings by
children, and the risk of hostile persons (such as prisoners, criminal
suspects, an opponent in a fight, or an enemy soldier) grabbing the gun and
using it against the owner. Gun rights advocates fear mandatory smart gun
technology will make it more difficult to fire a gun when needed.

[Smith & Wesson](/wiki/Smith_%26_Wesson "Smith & Wesson") reached a settlement
in 2000 with the administration of President Bill Clinton, which included a
provision for the company to develop a [smart gun](/wiki/Smart_gun "Smart
gun"). A consumer boycott organized by the NRA and NSSF nearly drove the
company out of business and forced it to drop its smart gun plans.[58][59]

The New Jersey Childproof Handgun Law of 2002 requires that 30 months after
"personalized handguns are available" anywhere in the United States, only
smart guns may be sold in the state.[60] Some gun safety advocates worry that
by raising the stakes of introducing the technology, this law contributes to
opposition that has prevented smart guns from being sold anywhere in the
United States despite availability in other countries.

In 2014, a Maryland gun dealer dropped plans to sell the first smart gun in
the United States after receiving complaints and even death threats.[61]

#### _District of Columbia v.
Heller_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gun_politics_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: District of Columbia v. Heller")]

Main article: [District of Columbia v.
Heller](/wiki/District_of_Columbia_v._Heller "District of Columbia v. Heller")

In June 2008, in _District of Columbia v. Heller_ , the Supreme Court upheld
by a 5-4 vote the _Parker_ decision striking down the D.C. gun law. _Heller_
ruled that Americans have an individual right to possess firearms,
irrespective of membership in a militia, "for traditionally lawful purposes,
such as self-defense within the home."[62] However, in delivering the majority
opinion, Justice [Antonin Scalia](/wiki/Antonin_Scalia "Antonin Scalia") made
it clear that, like other rights, the right to bear arms is limited. He wrote:

> Like most rights, the Second Amendment right is not unlimited. It is not a
> right to keep and carry any weapon whatsoever in any manner whatsoever and
> for whatever purpose: For example, concealed weapons prohibitions have been
> upheld under the Amendment or state analogues. The Court's opinion should
> not be taken to cast doubt on longstanding prohibitions on the possession of
> firearms by felons and the mentally ill, or laws forbidding the carrying of
> firearms in sensitive places such as schools and government buildings, or
> laws imposing conditions and qualifications on the commercial sale of arms.
> We also recognize another important limitation on the right to keep and
> carry arms. _Miller_ said, as we have explained, that the sorts of weapons
> protected were those "in common use at the time."...We think that limitation
> is fairly supported by the historical tradition of prohibiting the carrying
> of "dangerous and unusual weapons."[63][64]

The four dissenting justices said that the majority had broken established
precedent on the Second Amendment,[65] and took the position that the
Amendment refers to an individual right, but in the context of militia
service.[66][67][68][69]

#### _McDonald v. City of
Chicago_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gun_politics_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: McDonald v. City of Chicago")]

Main article: [McDonald v. City of Chicago](/wiki/McDonald_v._City_of_Chicago
"McDonald v. City of Chicago")

In June 2010, a Chicago law that banned handguns was struck down. The ruling
stated that "The Fourteenth Amendment makes the Second Amendment right to keep
and bear arms fully applicable to the States."

#### Advocacy groups, PACs, and
lobbying[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gun_politics_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Advocacy groups, PACs, and lobbying")]

One way advocacy groups influence politics is through "outside spending,"
using [political action committees](/wiki/Political_action_committee
"Political action committee") (PACs) and [501(c)(4)](/wiki/501\(c\)\(4\)
"501\(c\)\(4\)") organizations.[70] PACs and 501(c)(4)s raise and spend money
to affect elections.[71][72] PACs pool campaign contributions from members and
donate those funds to candidates for political office.[73] [Super
PACs](/wiki/Super_PACs "Super PACs"), created in 2010, are prohibited from
making direct contributions to candidates or parties, but influence races by
running ads for or against specific candidates.[74] Both gun control and gun
rights advocates use these types of organizations.

The NRA's Political Victory Fund super PAC spent $11.2 million in the 2012
election cycle,[75] and as of April 2014, it had raised $13.7 million for 2014
elections.[76] [Michael Bloomberg](/wiki/Michael_Bloomberg "Michael
Bloomberg")'s gun-control super PAC, Independence USA, spent $8.3 million in
2012[77][78] and $6.3 million in 2013.[79] [Americans for Responsible
Solutions](/wiki/Americans_for_Responsible_Solutions "Americans for
Responsible Solutions"), another gun-control super PAC started by retired
Congresswoman [Gabrielle Giffords](/wiki/Gabrielle_Giffords "Gabrielle
Giffords"), raised $12 million in 2013,[80] and plans to raise $16 to $20
million by the 2014 elections.[81] The group's treasurer said that the funds
would be enough to compete with the NRA "on an even-keel basis."[81]

Another way advocacy groups influence politics is through
[lobbying](/wiki/Lobbying "Lobbying"); some groups use lobbying firms, while
others employ in-house lobbyists. According to the [Center for Responsive
Politics](/wiki/Center_for_Responsive_Politics "Center for Responsive
Politics"), gun politics groups with the most lobbyists in 2013 were: the
NRA's Institute for Legislative Action ([NRA-ILA](/wiki/NRA-ILA "NRA-ILA"));
[Mayors Against Illegal Guns](/wiki/Mayors_Against_Illegal_Guns "Mayors
Against Illegal Guns") (MAIG); the [National Shooting Sports
Foundation](/wiki/National_Shooting_Sports_Foundation "National Shooting
Sports Foundation") (NSSF); and the Brady Campaign.[82] Gun rights groups
spent over $15.1 million lobbying in Washington D.C. in 2013, with the
[National Association for Gun
Rights](/wiki/National_Association_for_Gun_Rights "National Association for
Gun Rights") (NAGR) spending $6.7 million, and the NRA spending $3.4
million.[83] Gun control groups spent $2.2 million, with MAIG spending $1.7
million, and the [Brady Campaign](/wiki/Brady_Campaign "Brady Campaign")
spending $250,000 in the same period.[84]

#### 3D printed
firearms[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gun_politics_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: 3D printed firearms")]

Main article: [3D printed firearms](/wiki/3D_printed_firearms "3D printed
firearms")

In August 2012, an [open source](/wiki/Open_source "Open source") group called
[Defense Distributed](/wiki/Defense_Distributed "Defense Distributed")
launched a project to design and release a blueprint for a
[handgun](/wiki/Handgun "Handgun") that could be downloaded from the Internet
and manufactured using a [3-D printer](/wiki/3D_printing "3D
printing").[85][86] In May 2013, the group made public the
[STL](/wiki/STL_\(file_format\) "STL \(file format\)") files for the world's
first fully 3D printable gun, the [Liberator](/wiki/Liberator_\(gun\)
"Liberator \(gun\)") .380 [single shot](/wiki/Single_Shot#Pistols "Single
Shot") pistol.[87][88][89]

#### Proposals made by Obama
Administration[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gun_politics_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Proposals made by Obama Administration")]

On January 16, 2013, in response to the [Sandy Hook Elementary School
shooting](/wiki/Sandy_Hook_Elementary_School_shooting "Sandy Hook Elementary
School shooting") and other mass shootings, President [Barack
Obama](/wiki/Barack_Obama "Barack Obama") announced a plan for reducing gun
violence in four parts: closing background check loopholes; banning assault
weapons and large capacity magazines; making schools safer; and increasing
access to mental health services.[90][91]:2 The plan included proposals for
new laws to be passed by Congress, and a series of executive actions not
requiring Congressional approval.[90][92][93] No new federal gun control
legislation was passed as a result of these proposals.[94] President Obama
later stated in a 2015 interview with the [BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC") that [gun
control](/wiki/Gun_control "Gun control"):

> has been the one area where I feel that I've been most frustrated and most
> stymied, it is the fact that the United States of America is the one
> advanced nation on earth in which we do not have sufficient common-sense,
> gun-safety laws. Even in the face of repeated mass killings. And you know,
> if you look at the number of Americans killed since 9/11 by terrorism, it's
> less than 100. If you look at the number that have been killed by gun
> violence, it's in the tens of thousands. And for us not to be able to
> resolve that issue has been something that is distressing. But it is not
> something that I intend to stop working on in the remaining 18 months.[95]

#### Executive actions taken by the Obama
Administration[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gun_politics_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Executive actions taken by the Obama Administration")]

The executive actions included:

  * Improve the data used for the background check system for gun sales;
  * Direct the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to research gun violence;[96]
  * Provide incentives for schools to hire [school resource officers](/wiki/School_resource_officer "School resource officer");
  * Give law enforcement additional tools to prevent and prosecute gun crime.

In 2016, Obama called for a "sense of urgency" against gun violence[97] and
made several changes to [gun control](/wiki/Gun_control "Gun control")
enforcement,[98][99] including:

  * requiring a license and background check conduction for all gun distributors (cf. [gun show loophole](/wiki/Gun_show_loophole "Gun show loophole"));
  * extend background checks for guns purchased via a trust or corporation;
  * extend data available for [background checks](/wiki/Background_checks "Background checks") and improve response time (to close the [Charleston loophole](/w/index.php?title=Charleston_loophole&action=edit&redlink=1 "Charleston loophole \(page does not exist\)")).[100]

#### 2013 United Nations Arms
Treaty[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gun_politics_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: 2013 United Nations Arms Treaty")]

See also: [Arms Trade Treaty § Content](/wiki/Arms_Trade_Treaty#Content "Arms
Trade Treaty")

The [Arms Trade Treaty](/wiki/Arms_Trade_Treaty "Arms Trade Treaty") (ATT) is
a [multilateral treaty](/wiki/Multilateral_treaty "Multilateral treaty") that
regulates the international trade in [conventional
weapons](/wiki/Conventional_weapons "Conventional weapons"), which entered
into force on December 24, 2014.[101] Work on the treaty commenced in 2006
with negotiations for its content conducted at a global conference under the
auspices of the United Nations from July 2–27, 2012, in New York.[102] As it
was not possible to reach an agreement on a final text at that time, a new
meeting for the conference was scheduled for March 18–28, 2013.[103] On April
2, 2013, the [UN General Assembly](/wiki/UN_General_Assembly "UN General
Assembly") [adopted](/wiki/List_of_resolutions_at_the_sixty-
seventh_session_of_the_United_Nations_General_Assembly "List of resolutions at
the sixty-seventh session of the United Nations General Assembly") the
ATT.[104][105] The treaty was opened for signing on June 3, 2013 and by August
15, 2015 it had been signed by 130 states and ratified or acceded to by 72. It
entered into force on December 24, 2014 after it was ratified and acceded to
by 50 states.[106]

On September 25, 2013, [Secretary of State](/wiki/Secretary_of_State
"Secretary of State") [John Kerry](/wiki/John_Kerry "John Kerry") signed the
ATT on behalf of the [Obama administration](/wiki/Obama_administration "Obama
administration"). This was a reversal of the position of the [Bush
administration](/wiki/Presidency_of_George_W._Bush "Presidency of George W.
Bush") which had chosen not to participate in the treaty negotiations. Then in
October a bipartisan group of 50 [Senators](/wiki/United_States_Senate "United
States Senate") and 181
[Representatives](/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives "United States
House of Representatives") released concurrent letters to President [Barack
Obama](/wiki/Barack_Obama "Barack Obama") pledging their opposition to
ratification of the ATT. The group is led by Senator [Jerry
Moran](/wiki/Jerry_Moran "Jerry Moran")
([R](/wiki/Republican_Party_\(United_States\) "Republican Party \(United
States\)")-[Kansas](/wiki/Kansas "Kansas")) and Representatives [Mike
Kelly](/wiki/Mike_Kelly_\(Pennsylvania\) "Mike Kelly \(Pennsylvania\)")
(R-[Pennsylvania](/wiki/Pennsylvania "Pennsylvania")) and [Collin
Peterson](/wiki/Collin_Peterson "Collin Peterson")
([D](/wiki/Democratic_Party_\(United_States\) "Democratic Party \(United
States\)")-[Minnesota](/wiki/Minnesota "Minnesota")). Following these two
letters, four Democrat Senators sent a separate letter to the President
stating that "because of unaddressed concerns that this Treaty's obligations
could undermine our nation's sovereignty and the Second Amendment rights of
law-abiding Americans [they] would oppose the Treaty if it were to come before
the U.S. Senate." The four Senators are [Jon Tester](/wiki/Jon_Tester "Jon
Tester") (D-[Montana](/wiki/Montana "Montana")), [Max Baucus](/wiki/Max_Baucus
"Max Baucus") (D-Montana), [Heidi Heitkamp](/wiki/Heidi_Heitkamp "Heidi
Heitkamp") (D-North Dakota), and [Joe Donnelly](/wiki/Joe_Donnelly "Joe
Donnelly") (D-Indiana).[107][108]

Supporters of the treaty claim that the treaty is needed to help protect
millions around the globe in danger of human rights abuses. [Frank
Jannuzi](/wiki/Frank_Jannuzi "Frank Jannuzi") of [Amnesty International
USA](/wiki/Amnesty_International_USA "Amnesty International USA") states,
"This treaty says that nations must not export arms and ammunition where there
is an 'overriding risk' that they will be used to commit serious human rights
violations. It will help keep arms out of the hands of the wrong people: those
responsible for upwards of 1,500 deaths worldwide every day."[109] Secretary
Kerry was quoted as saying that his signature would "help deter the transfer
of conventional weapons used to carry out the world's worst crimes."[110] As
of December 2013, the U.S. has not ratified or acceded to the treaty.

## Public
opinion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gun_politics_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Public opinion")]

Main article: [Public opinion on gun control in the United
States](/wiki/Public_opinion_on_gun_control_in_the_United_States "Public
opinion on gun control in the United States")

###
Polls[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gun_politics_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Polls")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/March_on_Washington_for_Gun_Control_026.JPG/220px-
March_on_Washington_for_Gun_Control_026.JPG)](/wiki/File:March_on_Washington_for_Gun_Control_026.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:March_on_Washington_for_Gun_Control_026.JPG "Enlarge")

March on Washington for Gun Control in January 2013

_Huffington Post_ reported in September 2013 that 48% of Americans said gun
laws should be made more strict, while 16% said they should be made less
strict and 29% said there should be no change.[111] Similarly, a Gallup poll
found that support for stricter gun laws has fallen from 58% after the
[Newtown shooting](/wiki/Sandy_Hook_Elementary_School_shooting "Sandy Hook
Elementary School shooting"), to 49% in September 2013.[111] Both the
Huffington Post poll and the Gallup poll were conducted after the [Washington
Navy Yard shooting](/wiki/Washington_Navy_Yard_shooting "Washington Navy Yard
shooting").[111] Meanwhile, the Huffington Post poll found that 40% of
Americans believe stricter gun laws would prevent future mass shootings, while
52% said changing things would not make a difference.[111] The same poll also
found that 57% of Americans think better mental health care is more likely to
prevent future mass shootings than stricter gun laws, while 29% said the
opposite.[111]supported stricter gun laws, but 89% of those who thought that
such checks were not universally required supported stricter laws.[112]

In a 2015 study conducted by the [Law Center to Prevent Gun
Violence](/wiki/Law_Center_to_Prevent_Gun_Violence "Law Center to Prevent Gun
Violence"), state gun laws were examined based on various policy approaches,
and were scored on grade-based and ranked scales.[113] States were rated
positively for having passed stricter measures and stronger gun laws. Positive
points were also given for states that required background checks on all
firearm sales and limit bulk firearms purchases, prohibiting sales of assault
weapons and large capacity magazines, stricter evaluation on applications when
issuing a handgun concealed carry license especially prohibited domestic
violence offenders. Points were deducted from states with laws that expanded
access to guns, allowed concealed carry in public areas particularly schools
and bars without a permit or passed "Stand Your Ground Laws" — which remove
the duty to retreat and allow people to shoot potential assailants.
Eventually, states were graded indicating the overall strengths or weakness of
gun laws. Ten States with the strongest gun laws ranked from strongest
starting with California, then New Jersey, Massachusetts, Connecticut, Hawaii,
New York, Maryland, Illinois, Rhode Island and finally Michigan. The states
with weakest gun laws were ranked as follow: South Dakota, Arizona,
Mississippi, Vermont, Louisiana, Montana, Wyoming, Kentucky, Kansas, and
Oklahoma. A comparable study of state laws was also conducted in 2016.[114]
Based on these findings, The Law Center concluded that comprehensive gun laws
reduce gun violence deaths, whereas weaker guns laws increase gun-related
deaths. Furthermore, among different kinds of legislation, universal
background checks were the most effective at reducing gun-related deaths.[115]

#### Gallup
poll[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gun_politics_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Gallup poll")]

The Gallup organization regularly polls Americans on their views on guns. On
December 22, 2012:[116]

  * 44% supported a ban on "semi-automatic guns known as assault weapons."
  * 92% supported background checks on all gun-show gun sales.
  * 62% supported a ban on "high-capacity ammunition magazines that can contain more than 10 rounds."

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Vigil_of_solidarity_in_the_wake_of_the_Orlando_Pulse_shooting_%2827027482763%29.jpg/220px-
Vigil_of_solidarity_in_the_wake_of_the_Orlando_Pulse_shooting_%2827027482763%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vigil_of_solidarity_in_the_wake_of_the_Orlando_Pulse_shooting_\(27027482763\).jpg)

On April 25, 2013:[117]

  * 56% supported reinstating and strengthening the assault weapons ban of 1994.
  * 83% supported requiring background checks for all gun purchases.
  * 51% supported limiting the sale of ammunition magazines to those with 10 rounds or less.

On October 6, 2013:[118]

  * 49% felt that gun laws should be more strict.
  * 74% opposed civilian handgun bans.
  * 37% said they had a gun in their home.
  * 27% said they personally owned a gun.
  * 60% of gun owners have guns for personal safety/protection, 36% for hunting, 13% for recreation/sport, 8% for target shooting, 5% as a Second Amendment right.

In January 2014:[119]

  * 40% are satisfied with the current state of gun laws, 55% are dissatisfied
  * 31% want stricter control, 16% want less strict laws

On October 19, 2015:[120]

  * 55% said the law on _sales_ of firearms should be more strict, 33% kept as they are, 11% less strict 
    * this was sharply polarised by party, with 77% of Democrat supporters wanting stricter laws, against 27% of Republicans
  * 72% continued to oppose civilian handgun bans.

#### National Rifle
Association[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Gun_politics_in_the_United_States&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: National Rifle Association")]

A member poll conducted for the NRA between January 13 and 14, 2013
found:[121]

  * 90.7% of members favor "Reforming our mental health laws to help keep firearms out of the hands of people with mental illness." (A majority of 86.4% believe that strengthening laws this way would be more effective at preventing mass murders than banning semi-automatic rifles.)
  * 92.2% of NRA members oppose gun confiscation via mandatory buy-back laws.
  * 88.5% oppose banning [semi-automatic firearms](/wiki/Semi-automatic_firearm "Semi-automatic firearm"), firearms that load a new cartridge automatically when discharged.
  * 92.6% oppose a law requiring gun owners to register with the federal government.
  * 92.0% oppose a federal law banning the sale of firearms between private citizens.
  * 82.3% of members are in favor of a program that would place armed security professionals in every school.
  * 72.5% agreed that President Obama's ultimate goal is the confiscation of many firearms that are currently legal.
